revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=May 2015}} {{featured article}} {{Infobox military unit |unit_name=No. 33 Squadron RAAF |image=[[File:33SqnRAAFCrest.jpg|120px]] |caption=No. 33 Squadron's crest |allegiance=Australia |branch=[[Royal Australian Air Force]] |command_structure=[[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 Wing]] |garrison=[[RAAF Base Amberley]] |role=Air-to-air refuelling
Strategic transport |dates= 1942–46
1983–current |motto=Enduring |battles=World War II *[[New Guinea campaign]] [[Operation Solace]]
[[Operation Southern Watch]]
[[Operation Slipper|War in Afghanistan]]
[[2014 military intervention against ISIS|Military intervention against ISIS]] |identification_symbol= |identification_symbol_label=Callsign |equipment=[[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30]] |equipment_label=Aircraft }} '''No. 33 Squadron''' is a [[Royal Australian Air Force]] (RAAF) strategic transport and [[aerial refueling|air-to-air refuelling]] squadron. It operates [[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30A Multi Role Tanker Transports]] from [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland. The squadron was formed in February 1942 for service during World War II, operating [[Short Empire]] flying boats and a variety of smaller aircraft. By 1944 it had completely re-equipped with [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Douglas C-47 Dakota]] transports, which it flew in New Guinea prior to disbanding in May 1946. The unit was re-established in February 1981 as a [[flight (military unit)|flight]], equipped with two [[Boeing 707]]s for [[Very Important Person|VIP]] and other long-range transport duties out of [[RAAF Base Richmond]], New South Wales. No. 33 Flight was re-formed as a full squadron in July 1983. By 1988 it was operating six 707s, four of which were subsequently converted for aerial refuelling. The 707s saw active service during operations in Namibia, Somalia, the Persian Gulf, and Afghanistan. One of the transport jets was lost in a crash in October 1991. No. 33 Squadron relocated to Amberley and was temporarily without aircraft following the retirement of the 707s in June 2008. It began re-equipping with KC-30As in June 2011, and achieved [[initial operating capability]] with the type in February 2013. One of its aircraft was deployed to the Middle East in September 2014, as part of Australia's contribution to the [[2014 military intervention against ISIS|military coalition against ISIS]]. ==Role and equipment== [[File:RAAF Aircraftswoman providing a safety brief onboard a KC-30.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|alt= Woman in olive-green fatigues holding passenger oxygen mask in aircraft cabin|No. 33 Squadron [[Aircraftman|aircraftwoman]] giving a safety brief aboard an Airbus KC-30 in February 2013]] No. 33 Squadron is responsible for [[aerial refueling|aerial refuelling]] and long-range transport.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Lift-Group/No.-86-Wing/No.-33-Squadron/?RAAF-XHfJqcIhFO+qHJuxeBSgFgWfK7PwJ56L|title=No. 33 Squadron's role|publisher=[[Royal Australian Air Force]]|accessdate=20 July 2013}} It is located at [[RAAF Base Amberley]], Queensland, and controlled by [[No. 86 Wing RAAF|No. 86 Wing]], which is part of [[Air Mobility Group RAAF|Air Mobility Group]].{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=6&iid=91526|last=Hamilton|first=Eamon|title=Symbolic change is perfect timing|magazine=Air Force |volume=56 |issue=8|date=8 May 2014|page=7|accessdate=5 May 2014}} The unit headquarters comprises executive, administrative and operational components. As well as aircrew, the squadron is staffed by maintenance personnel responsible for regular aircraft service. Heavier maintenance is conducted by Northrop Grumman Integrated Defence Services (formerly [[Qantas Defence Services]]).{{cite magazine|url=http://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/northrop-completes-acquisition-of-qantas-defence-services-396445/|title=Northrop completes acquisition of Qantas Defence Services|magazine=[[Flight Global]]|date=28 February 2014 |accessdate=12 March 2015}} The squadron operates five [[Airbus A330 MRTT|Airbus KC-30A Multi Role Tanker Transports]], the first of which entered service in June 2011.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=628|title=First KC-30A arrived|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 16 June 2013}} Two more are due for delivery in 2018.{{cite magazine|title=RAAF to acquire two additional KC-30s|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2015/07/raaf-to-acquire-two-additional-kc-30s/|accessdate=4 July 2015|magazine=[[Australian Aviation (magazine)|Australian Aviation]]|date=1 July 2015}} The aircraft are crewed by pilots, refuelling operators and flight attendants. Air-to-air refuelling is considered a [[Force multiplication|force multiplier]], permitting the RAAF to increase the range and [[Loiter (flight)|loiter time]] of its aircraft. The ability to refuel in flight also enables aircraft to take off with more [[Aircraft ordnance|ordnance]] than they might otherwise. The KC-30 can carry up to 100 tonnes of fuel.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/About-us/Structure-of-the-RAAF/Air-Command/Air-Lift-Group/No.-86-Wing/No.-33-Squadron/?RAAF-XHfJqcIhFO+qHJuxeBSgFgWfK7PwJ56L|title=No. 33 Squadron's aircraft|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|accessdate=20 July 2013}} Its dual delivery systems—probe-and-drogue in the wings and boom under the tail—are designed to refuel the RAAF's [[McDonnell Douglas F/A-18 Hornet]] and [[Boeing F/A-18 Super Hornet]] multi-role fighters, [[Boeing C-17 Globemaster III]] heavy airlifters, [[Boeing 737 AEW&C|Boeing E-7 Wedgetail]] early warning aircraft, or other KC-30s.{{cite magazine|title=RAAF's KC-30 service ready|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2013/02/raafs-kc-30-service-ready/|accessdate=10 March 2013|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=26 February 2013}} The tanker is also capable of refuelling future acquisitions including the [[Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II|Lockheed Martin F-35A Lightning II]] stealth fighter, the [[Boeing EA-18G Growler]] electronic warfare aircraft, and the [[Boeing P-8A Poseidon]] maritime patrol aircraft.{{cite web|url=http://www.minister.defence.gov.au/2015/07/01/minister-for-defence-two-additional-kc-30a-multi-role-tanker-transport-aircraft-for-the-raaf/|title=Two additional KC-30A Multi-Role Tanker Transport aircraft for the RAAF|publisher=[[Department of Defence (Australia)|Department of Defence]]|date=1 July 2015|accessdate=4 July 2015}} In its transport configuration, the KC-30 can carry 270 passengers or 40 tonnes of cargo.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Air Force (newspaper)|Air Force News]], Vol. 47, No. 2 |date=24 February 2005 |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/EDITIONS/4702/topstories/story12.htm |title=New tankers to take on many roles|accessdate= 4 November 2013}} As well as its aircraft, No. 33 Squadron operates a {{nowrap|KC-30}} simulator at Amberley.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=18&iid=83495#folio=18|last=Wiseman|first=Nick|title=Almost like the real thing|magazine=Air Force |volume=55 |issue=21|date= 7 November 2013|page=19|accessdate= 4 November 2013}} ==History== ===World War II=== [[File:No. 33 Sqn Dragon (AWM P01877.004).jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|No. 33 Squadron de Havilland Dragon at [[Kokoda]], New Guinea, in February 1943| alt=Military personnel and a jeep in front of a twin-engined biplane, with jungle and a mountain range in the background]] During February and March 1942, the RAAF formed four transport units: Nos. 33, [[No. 34 Squadron RAAF|34]], [[No. 35 Squadron RAAF|35]] and [[No. 36 Squadron RAAF|36 Squadrons]]. No. 33 Squadron was established on 16 February at [[RAAF Base Townsville|Townsville]], Queensland, under the control of [[North-Eastern Area Command (RAAF)|North-Eastern Area Command]].Gillison, [http://static.awm.gov.au/images/collection/pdf/RCDIG1070516--1-.PDF ''Royal Australian Air Force'', p. 481]RAAF Historical Section, ''Maritime and Transport Units'', pp. 35–38 It was equipped with four ex-[[Qantas]] [[Short Empire]] flying boats transferred from [[No. 11 Squadron RAAF|No. 11 Squadron]], along with several smaller types including [[de Havilland Dragon]]s and [[de Havilland Tiger Moth|Tiger Moth]]s, [[Avro Anson]]s, and [[Stinson L-1 Vigilant|Vultee Vigilant]]s.Eather, ''Flying Squadrons'', pp. 68–69 Less than two weeks later the squadron suffered its first loss when one of the Empires crashed on landing at Townsville; the six crew members were killed. A second Empire was destroyed at its mooring during a [[Attack on Broome|Japanese air attack on Broome]], Western Australia, on 3 March; another Empire was impressed from Qantas to replace the lost aircraft. One of the squadron's tasks was search-and-rescue; it lost another Empire on 8 August 1942 after it sank in heavy seas off the coast of New Guinea while trying to rescue survivors of a [[torpedo]]ed ship. No. 33 Squadron transferred to [[Port Moresby]] in January 1943, providing air transport to Australian forces involved in the [[New Guinea campaign]]. Transport needs were so desperate in New Guinea that even the Tiger Moths were employed, delivering a total of {{convert|77|kg|lbs}} per trip. In September–October 1943, the squadron began taking delivery of fifteen [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|Douglas C-47 Dakotas]] to replace its assortment of aircraft. By the time it transferred to [[Milne Bay]] on 1 January 1944, it was operating Dakotas exclusively, and continued to do so for the rest of the war. The squadron relocated to [[Lae]] on 15 January 1945. Following the end of hostilities in August 1945, it was tasked with repatriating service personnel and former [[Prisoner of war|prisoners of war]]. No. 33 Squadron returned to Townsville on 11 March 1946, and disbanded there on 13 May. ===Post-war re-establishment=== In 1978, the Australian government decided to purchase two passenger jets for strategic transport, primarily to mitigate what it saw as the risk of terrorist attack inherent in carrying [[Very Important Person|VIPs]] on commercial flights. Its attempts to procure one [[Boeing 727]] each from domestic carriers [[Ansett Australia|Ansett]] and [[Trans Australia Airlines|TAA]] were unsuccessful but, in December, Qantas agreed to sell the government two [[Boeing 707]]s for $14.5 million.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maritime and Transport Units'', pp. 38–40 Purchasing big jets for VIPs was controversial, but the 707s were also intended for general long-range transport, being capable of carrying cargo or up to 160 passengers.Roylance, ''Air Base Richmond'', pp. 107–108{{cite magazine|title=33 Squadron: operational airline|magazine=Air Force Today |volume=1 |issue=1|date =May 1996|pages=28–29}} The first was transferred to the RAAF in March 1979, and its inaugural Air Force flight took place on 22 April. Located at [[RAAF Base Richmond]], New South Wales, the 707s were initially operated by [[No. 37 Squadron RAAF|No. 37 Squadron]]. They were formed into No. 33 Flight under the command of [[Wing commander (rank)|Wing Commander]] J.D. Grierson on 2 February 1981. The [[Flight (military unit)|flight's]] first mission took place the same day, when it ferried RAAF members and their families to [[RMAF Butterworth|RAAF Base Butterworth]], Malaysia, a task that had previously necessitated a Qantas charter. [[File:RAAF EB-707 (33 Sqn) refuelling a US Navy F-A-18 Hornet (VFA-131).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|No. 33 Squadron Boeing 707 refuelling a [[United States Navy|US Navy]] {{nowrap|F/A-18}} Hornet during the war in Afghanistan, April 2002|alt=Air-to-air view of four-engined jet transport refuelling fighter plane]] On 1 July 1983, after the government procured two more 707s for $7.5 million from [[Worldways Canada]], No. 33 Flight was reorganised as No. 33 Squadron under Grierson's command. Responsible for transporting VIPs such as members of the [[British Royal Family]], the [[Governor-General of Australia|Governor-General]], the [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]], and the [[Pope]], the 707 also became the first RAAF aircraft to land in the [[Soviet Union]], the occasion being the funeral of [[Konstantin Chernenko]] in 1985. Along with Nos. 36 and 37 Squadrons, operating [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules]], No. 33 Squadron came under the control of No. 86 Wing, part of the newly established Air Lift Group (later Air Mobility Group), in February 1987. Routine servicing of the 707s and Hercules was the responsibility of [[No. 486 Squadron RAAF|No. 486 Squadron]], another component of No. 86 Wing.RAAF Historical Section, ''Maintenance Units'', pp. 70–71 Qantas undertook heavier maintenance of the 707s at its jet base in [[Sydney Airport|Mascot]].{{cite magazine|title=Keeping the Boeing going|magazine=Air Force Today |volume=1 |issue=2|date =July 1996|page=32}} The RAAF acquired three more 707s on 25 February 1988, following a $25 million purchase from [[Boeing Defense, Space & Security|Boeing Military]]. One of the airframes was non-flying, for spares only, and was nicknamed "Hulksbury".{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=David|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/national/last-raaf-707-gives-sydney-a-scare/2008/06/30/1214677946042.html|title=Last RAAF 707 gives Sydney a scare|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=1 July 2008|accessdate= 16 June 2013}} A consortium of [[Israel Aerospace Industries]] and [[de Havilland Australia|Hawker de Havilland]] converted four of No. 33 Squadron's six serviceable aircraft to in-flight refuelling tankers between December 1988 and May 1992. Their probe-and-drogue configuration allowed them to refuel the RAAF's F/A-18 Hornets and the [[Royal New Zealand Air Force]]'s [[Douglas A-4 Skyhawk|Douglas A-4K Skyhawks]], but not the RAAF's [[General Dynamics F-111C|General Dynamics F-111]] bombers, which required a boom system; the other two 707s continued to be used purely for long-range transport. The RAAF had argued for an air-to-air refuelling capability for both the {{nowrap|F/A-18s}} and the {{nowrap|F-111s}}, but the Australian government refused to fund the latter, considering the F-111's existing range sufficient for deterrent purposes. Observers such as journalist Frank Cranston speculated that aside from any cost issues, the government was concerned that extending the bombers' range would signal to the region that Australia was adopting a more aggressive defence posture.Lax, ''From Controversy to Cutting Edge'', pp. 178–180Stephens, ''Power Plus Attitude'', p. 178 [[File:RAAF707-A20-261.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|alt=Boeing 707 nose and cockpit with toy kangaroo at open window and cartoon of a dragon on the fuselage, along with the words "33SQN B707", "''Castlereagh''" and "Royal International Air Tattoo 2006"|No. 33 Squadron Boeing 707 at [[Royal International Air Tattoo|RIAT]], 2006]] In April 1989, one of the 707s transported 300 [[Australian Army]] personnel in two flights to Namibia as part of the [[Australian contribution to UNTAG]], the United Nations Transition Assistance Group policing the country's transition to independence.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=665|title=No 33 Squadron B-707 ferried troops to Namibia|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 16 June 2013}} Later that year, the squadron helped ferry members of the Australian public when [[1989 Australian pilots' strike|the two domestic airlines were grounded during an industrial dispute]]; it was similarly employed in 1991 following the demise of [[Compass Airlines (Australia)|Compass Airlines]]. On 29 October 1991, one of the transport-configured 707s crashed into the sea during a training flight out of [[RAAF Base East Sale|East Sale]], Victoria; all five crew members were killed. The coronial inquest into this accident found that training in the asymmetric handling manoeuvre that caused the crash was deficient, and that the RAAF lacked a proper understanding of the handling characteristics of its 707s.{{cite web|title=B-707 lost in training accident|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=557|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 17 June 2013}} The Coroner's first recommendation related to the need for appropriate simulation for this type of training, an area not properly recognised or addressed by the RAAF at the time. State Coroner Victoria Report Case Nos. 3587, 3589, 3612, 3601, 3732/91 No. 33 Squadron transported Australian troops to and from Somalia as part of [[Operation Solace]] in 1993.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=131 |title=Advance party headed for Somalia|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 2 April 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=450|title=Airlift returned Army battalion from Somalia|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 2 April 2013}} In January 1998, still based at Richmond, No. 33 Squadron joined [[No. 32 Squadron RAAF|Nos. 32]] and 34 Squadrons under [[No. 84 Wing RAAF|No. 84 Wing]].{{cite magazine|magazine=Air Force News |volume=41 |issue=9|date= October 1999|page=18|title=Bulletin board}}Odgers, '' Air Force Australia'', p. 206 Two of No. 33 Squadron's aircraft were soon employed to form No. 84 Wing Detachment A in Kuwait, as part of [[Operation Southern Watch]]. On 5 March, one of the 707s undertook the first operational aerial tanker mission since the squadron's re-formation in 1983, when it refuelled six [[Panavia Tornado]]s of the [[Royal Air Force]] (RAF) over Saudi Arabia. The detachment subsequently refuelled US F/A-18 Hornets, [[Northrop Grumman EA-6B Prowler|Northrop Grumman EA-6 Prowlers]] and [[McDonnell Douglas AV-8B Harrier II|McDonnell Douglas AV-8 Harriers]], and RAF [[British Aerospace Harrier II|British Aerospace Harriers]], as well as the Tornados.{{cite magazine|magazine=Air Force News |volume=40 |issue=3|date= April 1998|page=1|title= Gulf 707s operational}}{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/minister/1998/07398.html|title=Australian Defence Force contingent deployment to the Gulf to continue|date=8 May 1998|publisher=Department of Defence|accessdate= 28 July 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502094454/http://www.defence.gov.au/minister/1998/07398.html|archivedate=2 May 2012}} From March to September 2002, two 707s formed No. 84 Wing Detachment as part of [[Operation Slipper|Australia's contribution to the war in Afghanistan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/minister/2002/1503022002.doc|title=Farewell of 84 WG Detachment|publisher=Department of Defence|date=15 March 2002|accessdate= 28 July 2013|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080819184833/http://defence.gov.au/minister/2002/1503022002.doc|archivedate=19 August 2008 }}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4419/topstories/story01.htm|last=Caddaye|first=Ben|title=Well done|magazine=Air Force |volume=44 |issue=19|date= 10 October 2002|accessdate= 4 November 2013}} Located at [[Transit Center at Manas|Manas Air Base]] in [[Kyrgyzstan]], the 707s provided aerial refuelling to coalition aircraft operating in the theatre, their efforts earning No. 84 Wing a [[Meritorious Unit Citation]].{{cite journal|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/health/infocentre/journals/ADFHJ_apr04/ADFHealth_5_1_bc.pdf|last=Seah|first=Mike|title=84 Wing Detachment, Ganci Air Base, Manas, Kyrgyzstan|work=ADF Health|page=Back cover|date=April 2004|accessdate= 18 May 2013}}{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4419/topstories/story02.htm|title=84WG awarded unit citation|magazine=Air Force |volume=44 |issue=19|date= 10 October 2002|accessdate= 18 May 2013}} ===Re-equipment=== [[File:RAAF KC-30A in Guam photo number 130201-O-ZZ999-003 (8454721042).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.2|alt=Grey-coloured twin-engined jet on runway|No. 33 Squadron Airbus KC-30 on a {{nowrap|multi-national}} exercise in [[Guam]], February 2013]] By the mid-1990s, the ageing 707s carrying Australian VIPs overseas were no longer compliant with foreign noise and emission regulations. No. 33 Squadron relinquished its VIP transport role in 2002, following the entry into service of No. 34 Squadron's [[Boeing Business Jet|Boeing 737 Business Jets]] and [[Bombardier Challenger 604]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.airforce.gov.au/raafmuseum/research/aircraft/series3/A37.htm|title=Challenger CL 604|publisher=[[RAAF Museum]]|accessdate= 18 May 2013}}{{cite journal|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate_Committees?url=fadt_ctte/estimates/sup_0809/def/ans_def_updated_q5_oct08.pdf|work=Budget Supplementary Estimates; October 2008|title=Answers to questions on notice from the Department of Defence|publisher=Department of Defence|date=27 January 2009|accessdate= 6 June 2013}} The squadron was awarded the [[Gloucester Cup]] in May 2007, "in recognition of its high levels of proficiency demonstrated over the year" in spite of the challenges of operating the obsolescent 707s, and for having "performed superbly on a number of high-profile missions".{{cite magazine|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/news/raafnews/editions/4909/features/feature1.htm|last=Paton|first=Simon|title=Good as gold|magazine=Air Force|volume =49|issue=9|date=31 May 2007|accessdate=2 July 2016}} The 707s were retired in 2008, bringing to an end the 29-year operational history of the type in the RAAF.{{cite web|url=http://www.defence.gov.au/media/AlertTpl.cfm?CurrentId=7905 |title=Boeing 707 Farewell Flights Over Sydney and Hawkesbury|publisher= Department of Defence |accessdate= 13 December 2008}} The last one in service, an ex-Qantas jet named "Richmond Town", made a low-level farewell flight over [[Sydney]] on 30 June in the company of smaller aircraft filming the occasion, which gave rise to fear in some quarters that a [[September 11 attacks|9/11]]-style terrorist attack was in progress.{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=571|title=Farewell B-707 flight|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate= 17 June 2013}} Three 707s remained at Richmond until 2011, when they were flown out by their new operator, the US-based [[Omega Aerial Refueling Services|Omega Air Services]]; Omega also procured the RAAF's Boeing simulator, which had been operated by [[No. 285 Squadron RAAF|No. 285 Squadron]].{{cite magazine|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2011/10/former-raaf-707s-flown-out-by-omega/|date=23 October 2011|title=Former RAAF 707s flown out by Omega|magazine=Australian Aviation|accessdate= 16 June 2013}} Following the retirement of the Boeing 707, No. 33 Squadron relocated to RAAF Base Amberley, Queensland, on 1 July 2008. It was presented with a [[Colours, standards and guidons|Squadron Standard]] by Queensland Governor [[Penelope Wensley]] on 2 June 2010, to commemorate "25 years of faithful and outstanding service".{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?iid=37407&xml=defencenews_airforce.xml&startpage=8 |title=Historic day for 33SQN|magazine=Air Force |volume=52 |issue=11|date=24 June 2010|page=9|accessdate=12 April 2014}} Having been without aircraft for three years, the squadron began re-equipping with the first of five Airbus KC-30A Multi Role Tanker Transports on 1 June 2011. The KC-30 could carry one-and-a-half times as much fuel as the 707 and was configured with both probe-and-drogue and boom delivery systems. These aircraft had originally been scheduled to enter service late in 2008, and the RAAF had to lease tankers from the [[United States Air Force]] and Omega Air to meet its aerial refuelling needs while Airbus rectified problems with the boom system and completed essential technical documentation.{{cite magazine|title=Airbus misses RAAF KC-30 MRTT delivery deadline|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2010/12/airbus-misses-raaf-kc-30-mrtt-delivery-deadline/|accessdate=17 June 2013|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=22 December 2010}}{{cite magazine|title=Boom or bust! – RAAF KC-30 loses boom|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2011/01/boom-or-bust-raaf-kc-30-loses-boom/|accessdate=19 June 2013|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=20 January 2011}} In March 2012, one of the KC-30s set a record for the number of passengers carried on an RAAF aircraft, 220 cadets from the [[Australian Defence Force Academy]].{{cite web|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/HistoryRecord/HistoryRecordDetail.aspx?rid=665|title=New passenger record set|publisher=Air Power Development Centre|accessdate=16 June 2013}} The squadron received its fifth KC-30 on 3 December 2012, and achieved [[initial operating capability]] in February 2013.{{cite journal|url=http://www.asiapacificdefencereporter.com/articles/277/Airbus-Military-delivers-final-A330-MRTT-to-Royal-Australian-Air-Force|title=Airbus Military delivers final A330 MRTT to Royal Australian Air Force|date=11 December 2012|accessdate=19 June 2013|work=Asia-Pacific Defence Reporter}} It expected to reach final operating capability, with both boom and probe-and-drogue delivery systems, in 2014.{{cite magazine|title=Improvements heading KC-30A towards FOC|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2013/05/improvements-heading-kc-30a-towards-foc/|accessdate=22 July 2013|magazine=Australian Aviation|date=30 May 2013}} On 14 September that year, the Federal government committed to deploying one of the squadron's KC-30s to [[Al Minhad Air Base]] in the United Arab Emirates, as part of a [[2014 military intervention against ISIS|coalition]] to combat [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant|Islamic State]] forces in Iraq. The aircraft was only cleared for operations with the probe-and-drogue system, as by this stage the boom system was not ready.{{cite news|title=RAAF headed back to Iraq|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2014/09/raaf-headed-back-to-iraq/|accessdate=15 September 2014|newspaper=Australian Aviation|date=15 September 2014}} The KC-30 began flying missions in Iraq on 1 October 2014.{{cite web|url=http://news.defence.gov.au/2014/10/02/australian-air-task-group-commences-operational-missions-over-iraq/|title=Australian Air Task Group commences operational missions over Iraq|publisher=Department of Defence|date=2 October 2014|accessdate=2 October 2014}} The first successful contact using the boom system (in concert with another RAAF KC-30) took place near Amberley on 13 May 2015.{{cite magazine|url=http://australianaviation.com.au/2015/05/raaf-executes-first-boom-contact-with-kc-30a/|date=15 May 2015|title=RAAF executes first boom contact with KC-30A|magazine=Australian Aviation|accessdate= 5 June 2015}} In July, the Federal government announced the purchase of two more KC-30s for delivery in 2018, taking No. 33 Squadron's fleet to seven aircraft; the airframes were to be ex-Qantas [[Airbus A330|A330-200]] passenger liners, converted by [[Airbus Defence and Space]] at [[Getafe]], near [[Madrid]]. The KC-30 deployed to Iraq undertook the first operational use of the boom system in late October 2015, refuelling an RAAF E-7 Wedgetail.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=6&iid=132788#folio=6 |title=Booming success for our tanker|magazine=Air Force |volume=57 |issue=23|date=3 December 2015|page=7|accessdate=30 November 2015}} In March 2016, No. 33 Squadron was awarded the [[Gloucester Cup|Duke of Gloucester Cup]] as the RAAF's most proficient squadron of the previous year, as well as the RAAF Maintenance Trophy.{{cite magazine|url=http://airforcenews.realviewdigital.com/?startpage=2&iid=138862 |title=And the winners are:|magazine=Air Force |volume=58 |issue=4|date=24 March 2016|page=3|accessdate=24 March 2016}} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== {{commons category|No. 33 Squadron RAAF}} *{{cite book|last=Eather|first=Steve|title=Flying Squadrons of the Australian Defence Force|publisher=Aerospace Publications|location=Weston Creek, Australian Capital Territory|year=1995|isbn=1-875671-15-3}} *{{cite book|last=Gillison|first=Douglas|title=Royal Australian Air Force 1939–1942 |url=https://www.awm.gov.au/collection/RCDIG1070209/|series=Australia in the War of 1939–1945. Series 3 – Air|volume=Volume 1|year=1962|publisher=Australian War Memorial |location=Canberra|oclc=2000369}} *{{cite book|last=Lax|first= Mark |url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/Details/431/From-Controversy-to-Cutting-Edge.aspx |title=From Controversy to Cutting Edge: A History of the F-111 in Australian Service|location= Canberra|publisher= Air Power Development Centre|year= 2010|isbn= 978-1-920800-54-3}} *{{cite book|last=Odgers | first=George |authorlink=George Odgers|origyear=1984| year=1996| title=Air Force Australia | location=Frenchs Forest, New South Wales| publisher=National Book Distributors| isbn=1-86436-081-X}} *{{cite book|author=RAAF Historical Section|year=1995|title=Units of the Royal Australian Air Force: A Concise History. Volume 4: Maritime and Transport Units|location=Canberra| publisher=[[Australian Government Publishing Service]]|isbn=0-644-42796-5}} *{{cite book|author=RAAF Historical Section|year=1995|title=Units of the Royal Australian Air Force: A Concise History. Volume 7: Maintenance Units|location=Canberra| publisher=Australian Government Publishing Service|isbn=0-644-42800-7}} *{{cite book|last=Roylance| first=Derek | year=1991| title=Air Base Richmond|location=RAAF Base Richmond|publisher=Royal Australian Air Force|isbn=0-646-05212-8}} *{{cite book|last=Stephens| first=Alan|year=1992|title=Power Plus Attitude: Ideas, Strategy and Doctrine in the Royal Australian Air Force 1921–1991|location=Canberra| publisher=Australian Government Publishing Service|url=http://airpower.airforce.gov.au/Publications/List/38/Historical-Titles.aspx?page=3|isbn=0-644-24388-0}} {{List of RAAF Squadrons}} {{Military units and formations of the Royal Australian Air Force}} [[Category:RAAF squadrons|33]] [[Category:Military units and formations established in 1942]] [[Category:Military units and formations of the Royal Australian Air Force in World War II]]
